keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris was the victim of a daylight robbery where jewellery worth 88 million euros was stolen in under eight minutes.
The Apollo Gallery, where the heist occurred, remains closed despite the museum's reopening.
Four masked thieves used mechanical ladders and a battery-powered disc cutter to break into the museum, cutting through glass and threatening guards.
The thieves were seen fleeing on scooters after attempting to set fire to their vehicle, which was stopped by a museum staff member.
A damaged crown from Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, suggesting the robbers dropped it during their getaway.
Security flaws were revealed, including one in three rooms lacking CCTV and an alarm system failure, prompting broader security upgrades across France.
President Emmanuel Macron urged faster implementation of security reforms, and the museum director Laurence des Cars is set to testify before the French Senate’s culture committee.
Interior Minister Laurent Nunez expressed confidence that the suspects will be caught, with prosecutors believing the group operated under criminal orders.
A preliminary report found that the gallery's alarm had been broken or deactivated, possibly indicating prior planning.
The museum has refunded visitors who had booked tickets, including Benjamin Carbajal from Peru, who expressed understanding of the seriousness of the event.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre Museum in Paris reopened three days after a brazen daylight heist in which thieves, using mechanical ladders and power tools, stole jewellery worth 88 million euros, including a necklace from Napoleon and a tiara from Empress Eugenie. The Apollo Gallery, where the robbery occurred, remains closed, and investigations have revealed serious security flaws, such as the absence of CCTV in one-third of rooms and a failed alarm system. President Emmanuel Macron and Interior Minister Laurent Nunez have emphasized the need for stronger security across France’s cultural institutions. The museum has refunded affected visitors, including Benjamin Carbajal from Peru, and prosecutors suspect the thieves were acting under criminal orders. A damaged crown from Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, and officials are confident the perpetrators will be identified and apprehended.
title: Louvre reopens three days after French crown jewels stolen
